data.description: The Four Dragon Kings are the divine rulers of the seas who control weather, rainfall, and all bodies of water in Chinese mythology. Dwelling in magnificent crystal palaces beneath the oceans, they command vast armies of aquatic creatures and serve under the authority of the Jade Emperor, regulating the waters that sustain all life.
data.title: Chinese - Dragon Kings
symbols: Wine and food: Elaborate feast offerings
Incense: Continuous burning at temple altars
Fishermen and sailors seeking safe voyages
Those living near rivers and coastlines
Anyone whose livelihood depends on water

data.name: Dragon Kings

data.description: Erlang Shen is the formidable three-eyed warrior god of Chinese mythology, nephew of the Jade Emperor and master of seventy-two transformations. Armed with his legendary three-pointed double-edged lance and accompanied by his celestial hound Xiaotian, he serves as heaven's greatest demon-slayer and one of the few beings capable of matching the Monkey King in combat.
data.title: Chinese - Erlang Shen
symbols: Wine: Offerings of alcohol for the warrior god
Hunters and those who work with dogs
Those seeking justice against powerful enemies
Wine: Offerings of alcohol for the warrior god
Hunters and those who work with dogs
Those seeking justice against powerful enemies

data.name: Erlang Shen

data.description: The Jade Emperor is the supreme ruler of heaven and earth in Chinese mythology, presiding over the celestial bureaucracy as the divine emperor who governs all gods, spirits, and mortal affairs. He embodies the Confucian ideal of the perfect sovereign: wise, just, compassionate, and absolute in authority.
data.title: Chinese - Jade Emperor
symbols: Tea and wine: Symbolizing respect and hospitality
Tea and wine: Symbolizing respect and hospitality

data.name: Jade Emperor

data.description: Nezha is the rebellious child-god of Chinese mythology, a fierce protector deity born from a lotus flower after sacrificing his mortal body. Known as the Marshal of the Central Altar and Third Lotus Prince, he wields cosmic weapons and rides flaming wheels, embodying youthful defiance, filial sacrifice, and divine redemption.
data.title: Chinese - Nezha
symbols: Toys and sweets: Reflecting his child nature
Roasted meats: Particularly duck and pork
Firecrackers: To honor his fiery nature
Toys and sweets: Reflecting his child nature
Roasted meats: Particularly duck and pork
Firecrackers: To honor his fiery nature

data.name: Nezha

data.description: Xi Wangmu is one of the oldest and most powerful goddesses in Chinese mythology, the immortal Queen who rules from her paradise on Mount Kunlun. Guardian of the Peaches of Immortality and keeper of the elixir of eternal life, she presides over female immortals and represents the ultimate yin principle of the cosmos.
domains: Supreme embodiment of cosmic yin energy
Represents the west, autumn, metal element
All female immortals are under her authority
Represents the goal of Daoist cultivation
data.title: Chinese - Xi Wangmu
symbols: Sweet foods: Cakes, candied fruits, sweet rice
Those seeking longevity and good health

data.description: Zao Jun is the domestic deity who watches over every Chinese household from his seat by the stove. As the Jade Emperor's official inspector of mortal families, he observes all that happens within the home and reports annually to heaven, determining each family's fortune for the coming year. He is one of the most intimately worshipped gods in Chinese folk religion.
data.title: Chinese - Zao Jun
